body:
Thanks for making an issue about this.

I suspect it might be quite a lot of work changing to the v2 API alas.

We could do the work now but stop the s3 backend compiling on anything less than go1.15.
That's fine. Just wanted to put this on your radar since v1 will eventually get deprecated now that v2 has been promoted to GA and there are some nice QoL improvements too.
hi, is anyone working on this?

@tareqhs not at the moment.  Is it something you are interested in helping with? What advantages do you think we'd get from the new API?

I dread having to port the service configuration from v1 to v2 as we don't have many tests and there are 100s of different ways of configuring it!

@ncw I'll count the benefits in an opinionated descending order:
1. v2 is taking over and v1 will be deprecated sooner or later. for corporate usage this is a significant factor.
1. performance improvement (claimed) - this is questionable and depends on the target scenarios.
1. the huge sdk has been broken to many submodules which is great for rclone because it uses the S3 submodule only.
1. the APIs have been modernized for go 1.15 (e.g. context usage) which aligns better with rclone's standards.

the configuration flow seems actually simpler in v2. I haven't performed a deep dive for rclone's use case though...

made a very small step in my own branch, probably will take time to finish so cooperation is welcome
https://github.com/rclone/rclone/compare/master...tareqhs:aws_sdk_v2

All good reasons, and it is generally our policy to keep up with dependencies.

Your branch doesn't look too scary at the moment. Does it work at all?

Does the V2 sdk let you call putobject without giving it an io.Seeker? Rclone only has io.Readers so that would be a major improvement if it does and would mean we could get rid of the presigned request which isn't very compatible with other S3 implementations (snowball doesn't support it).

@ncw Yes, v2 accepts a minimal `io.Reader` for `PutObject`:
https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/service/s3@v1.19.1#PutObjectInput

Since the change is big and affects a popular backend, I suggest we first reach parity with existing code and then start to refactor to make better use of v2's new facilities. Still I made a separate commit that replaces the bulky signed request with a simple direct usage of `io.Reader`.

I still don't have a fully compiled code but I've already migrated everything except for s3 client configuration, which shouldn't be that complicated. (I'll come back to this ASAP)

How can test this? Are there any test suites for rclone+s3 ?

> @ncw Yes, v2 accepts a minimal `io.Reader` for `PutObject`: https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/service/s3@v1.19.1#PutObjectInput

That's great!
 
> Since the change is big and affects a popular backend, I suggest we first reach parity with existing code and then start to refactor to make better use of v2's new facilities. Still I made a separate commit that replaces the bulky signed request with a simple direct usage of `io.Reader`.

That sounds like a good plan.

We could also temporarily fork the s3 backend into an s3v2 backend and have both in the codebase for a while so we could get more testing like that. Or we can make a branch and issue betas from the branch very easily.
 
> I still don't have a fully compiled code but I've already migrated everything except for s3 client configuration, which should be that complicated. (I'll come back to this ASAP)

OK

> How can test this? Are there any test suites for rclone+s3 ?

The best way to test is using [the integration tests](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#backend-testing). In brief you can run `go test` while in the `backend/s3` directory provided you've set up a `TestS3:` remote. This tests nearly all the backend features, so iterate until this passes. (Or use your existing remote with `go test -remote mys3remote:`)

To run all the integration tests you would then (from the source root)

    go install ./...
    test_all -remotes TestS3:

Which will run rclone's integration tests for sync/operations/vfs/backend/etc against `TestS3:` which is the comprehensive test! The integration test machine is configured to run this against quite a few different s3 providers.

This doesn't test the incredibly varied matrix of client configurations though - there aren't unit tests for those.

issue.title: Add custom provider in official rclone repo

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: Rclone patcher to add IAM support

issue.body:
- Avoid the patch system and add officially the INFN Cloud provider with `s3 + sts`
- Using `oidc-agent` as a token retrieving command

body: @ncw Looks like v1 will be going into Maintenance mode in July '24 & EOL in July '25: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/developer/announcing-end-of-support-for-aws-sdk-for-go-v1-on-july-31-2025/

We'd better get on with this :-) @tareksha made a start on this in https://github.com/tareksha/rclone/tree/aws_sdk_v2 - I doubt we'll be able to rebase that easily on master but it should give some pointers.

I will do this in v1.67 release unless I get any other takers before then? Maybe you'd like to continue @tareksha ?
